abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Nutrition and Early
            Childhood Development Project for Uganda were as follows:
            outcome moderately unsatisfactory, the Bank and the Borrower
            performance is rated as moderately unsatisfactory, and
            quality at entry is rated moderately satisfactory. A
            shortage of funds brought implementation to a halt after two
            years from the beginning of activities at the community
            level, and disbursement of grants to the communities was
            suspended. Eventually funds were obtained to resume
            implementation, but the project closed without attaining
            full completion. Some lessons learned included: large-scale
            participatory community planning can increase the impact and
            sustainability of the grassroots development process.
            Involving a large number of communities in a participatory
            rural appraisal (PRA) exercise is very challenging, but the
            Ugandan experience demonstrated that it is possible. There
            is reason to believe that the implementation structure that
            delivered in Uganda can be adapted for replication in other
            developing countries. This mechanism turned out to be very
            time consuming. In spite of this, the approach has been
            given high ratings from all involved in implementation and
            should be encouraged. Where communities are involved, it is
            crucial to complete activities once they commence. For two
            years, project communities were unsure if the project will
            continue. This lowered project credibility and raised
            planning fatigue. Such uncertainty places community
            motivation in jeopardy. The original plan to phase-in
            activities in different districts might have prevented the
            time gap between community action plan (CAP) planning and
            implementation. Also, to regain project credibility in the
            communities, it was important to complete community grants
            that were already planned.
